Once Igor appears on screen the movie shifts to his perspective. (Or, in a way, it clarifies the perspective it already had.) Baker expects us to be impressed that Igor views Ani as a human being. He seems to expect the same praise for himself. I’m not impressed. I’m impressed by his skills as a filmmaker. But I prefer a straight dude voyeur director to spare us the self-righteousness.

Appreciated this in ways I didn't expect at all: ridiculously amusing humour present throughout the entire thing, while profound sadness is so close - You'll be hard pressed to find a film with a more perfectly calibrated mix of anguish and comedy than this one. Absorbs you immediately with its powerful undercurrent and infectious appeal, takes you through an almost traditionally frenzied fish out of water story (with some of the most fucking hilarious single moments of the year), then overwhelms you to the point of total and utter sorrow. Such a significant project. Mikey Madison is likewise exceptional, as you might expect.
Mikey Motherfucking Madison <3

Anora is fun. I’ll say that. After all the hype over these last few months, I will say that it’s a fun movie. Mikey Madison is fantastic playing her. However, the fun can only go so far, and there’s not a lot of movie around it. I found its structure pretty well done in its triptych-esque form, but for a film called Anora, it’s not really into developing her. It's superficially entertaining and crafts a thrill ride around several ideas…

Anora — or “Ani,” as she prefers to be called — is a brassy, 23-year-old Russian-American stripper who shares a small house with her sister in Brighton Beach. Ivan — or “Vanya,” as he uses interchangeably — is the 21-year-old son of a Moscow billionaire who stays in his father’s cocaine mansion on the far side of Brooklyn whenever he’s in New York, which if it were up to him would be always. She works seven nights a week at…
These Russian billionaires didn’t stand a chance against the mouth on Anora.

This review may contain spoilers. I can handle the truth. ANORA is a carney ride of a movie and deserving of its awards and success but one point of logic left me puzzled. If Mikey is hard as nails why does she accept a $10G buyout when a contingency lawyer would have gotten her multiples of that with a single phone call. The film tries to sell this plot point by having her mother-in-law threaten her but the threat rings false given what we know of Anora.

Everyone has had their time wasted by somebody who doesn’t truly care for them, and everyone has hopelessly clung onto that person through the inevitable implosion. Coming out the other side, it’s hard to know what to do with yourself. In the aftermath, even a truly decent person can be scary as they are alluring. Settled dust is still dust, all it takes is another storm. This is the heart of Anora, crammed into one chaotic two week period and…

It’s sensual, funny, devastating and profoundly sad. We see a young girl who has always lived in conformity, stuck in routine and resigned to the life she has. She accepts her reality without questioning it, until someone appears who shows an apparently so genuine and welcoming affection that it makes her disconnect from the real world. It is not only affection, but an almost miraculous sense of security. Even hesitant at first, Ani believes she has found her prince charming…

Blinds you with its glittery lights and thrumming bass and disarming humor until you’re left on your knees sobbing. Can’t begin to fully articulate how immensely heavy Anora winds up feeling by its conclusion. Sean Baker is always able to tie the humor together with heartbreak, but I think this film is where that blend is especially concentrated and effective. Sat through the whole credits so I could cry in the dark and really let it settle. Radiantly evil. Works best when it’s a screwball comedy about a spoiled Russian teenager. I love the way he slides across the floor and runs up the stairs in his dad’s mansion. Reminds me of European international school kids. But then it becomes a repetitive cat-and-mouse chase where a lot of people talk over each other while also telegraphing the dumbest, most obvious ending imaginable. It’s the worst of Gerwig and the Safdies combined. Seen at the Walter Reade Theater at Film at Lincoln Center in New York City in 35mm

Whatever you want to call it - stylish romp, gritty fairytale, modern tragedy, Anora is undoubtably a technical feat. With a captivating lead performance by Mikey Madison, donning the thickest Coney Island accent she could conjure, and breathtaking camerawork, Sean Baker crafts an immersive, genuinely hilarious experience for us that’s impossible not to enjoy. One scene that sticks out in particular is when Ivan, the son of a Russian oligarch who hires Annie as his quasi-girlfriend, proposes to her in…

Contemporary cinema’s foremost chronicler of American dreamers and schemers hustling on the margins of capitalist promise, Sean Baker, reaches new heights of mastery with this audacious anti–Cinderella story—a whirlwind neorealist screwball comedy with an aching heart. In an electric, star-is-born performance, Mikey Madison soars as Anora, an enterprising, ferociously foulmouthed Brooklyn erotic dancer and sex worker whose Prince Not-So-Charming comes along in the form of a Russian oligarch’s wild-child son (Mark Eydelshteyn). ANORA is yet another chaotic, vivacious film from Sean Baker exploring the American Dream through themes of adult independence & the rewards of hard work. Stressful, loud & sweet, with plenty of laughs and a gut-punch of an ending. Mikey Madison, already a standout in supporting roles, radiates star power with her feisty fierceness and emotional vulnerability, making her an engrossing actress to watch. As significant of a film as this might be for Sean Baker, Madison’s big moment has arrived.My full review here

63Not fully successful, but like Sean Baker's other films, Anora buzzes on a base level of high-wire spontaneity that eventually won me over. Can't quite praise the ambling middle third, which attempts a labyrinthine mix of screwball and nocturnal odyssey only to grate on my nerves, although the beginning/end keep the film memorable in my mind as a whole. Features well-drawn comic performances that are weaponized as tragic totems of capitalism's destruction. Excited to see where Sean Baker goes from here.

I've always respected Baker's naysayers even if I could never really agree with where they were coming from vis-à-vis his supposed social tourism and self-defeating apoliticism. But despite the across-the-board strong performances here, Anora is where he hit a wall for me. Among other things, Baker's nonjudgmental approach to the recurring topic of sex work has yielded fewer and fewer insights from his high-water mark of Tangerine, not coincidentally the film where he solicited the most collaborative input from his…

Probably the most demonstrable case of the flaws in Sean Baker’s inclination towards mining marginalized communities for art. I’ve never quite ascribed to the notion of “social tourism” in his work like some have, but it’s always been an interesting question to raise, and I think Anora lays things to bare here in a telling way. So much of the press tour of the movie has been devoted to how they got input from real sex workers and strippers, but…

I see a lot of complaints about how little agency Anora is given throughout the movie despite the movie being named after her. I disagree. We do not know what Ani thinks. The movie is very intentional about not explicitly stating how much of her involvement with Vanya was emotional and how much was transactional. The…

Anora is strongest in its first act, a shimmering fantasy whirlwind undergirded by a deeply humanist lens, every second of genuine laughter accompanied by a fleeting sense of uncertainty, realism, even foreboding - in other words, a Sean Baker film in the best way. I had to rewatch… Anora won Best Film at the Critics Choice Awards, and honestly, this feels like a win for independent cinema as a whole. It’s the kind of film that reminds you why cinema matters in the first place.One of the things I love most about Baker’s…

No solo es una tragedia contada en tono de screwball comedy sino que además es una película que se permite, como es usual en el cine de Baker, cuestionar esta mentalidad meritocrata y basada en la idea del sueño americano. A ambiguidade da Anora é a melhor coisa do filme, uma eterna indecisão entre malícia e inocência da personagem, que está diante de um possível grande amor – e da realização do sonho americano – que pode se tornar um pesadelo. O Sean Baker usa isso pra construir um filme sobre o fracasso desse sonho, mas dá umas escorregadas imperdoáveis.Eu não consigo conceber a ideia de apresentar uma personagem tão interessante e, em vez de continuar a desenvolvendo, a…

I think this movie has the weirdest birthday you can have.I admire how Baker portrays sex, partying, and the so-called "living life" in a world where some are indulging in excess while others are left cleaning up the mess. The film’s autonomy is questioned, as the narrative’s outcome feels too perfect to be real. Power, money, control and their intricate battle unfold in a world where everyone is in search of their own self-interest. Yet, everything must come from…

i do not know what you want me to do with this, sean baker, i really don’t.i don’t agree with every single criticism i’m seeing online about this, but the script lacks a lot of conviction so i can understand why people can jump to (occasionally bad-faith) conclusions. the film itself isn’t exactly counteracting the points they’re reaching.mikey madison does A LOT of work to try and make this salvageable. i do think the film does her a major disservice by relegating her to a side character in the grander plot, though

Anora sees Sean Baker reach new heights, as a propulsive, hugely enjoyable work that dreams big while keeping the core of his style intact. As with many of Baker's previous films, Anora relies on deadpan humour while telling a very real story about sex workers in a non-judgemental way. Every moment has a balance of painfully believable drama and very funny details. In fact Anora is probably Baker's funniest film, filled with laughs as characters shout and scream through a…

The ride is fun for a good bit, even if the first third stags very equanimouslyBut my main issue is that, we do not know Anora. We have a small foundation on who she is, what she does…but it kinda meanders. What we get was good, don’t get me wrong, but once the credits rolled, so did my eyes. Any visceral feelings were not invoked nor earned. Sorry 🤷‍♀️ It’s been a great ride, but I think we need to innovate storytelling of SW-ers that doesn’t reiterate.

I wasn't sure where things were going when the first 40 minutes was two people doing cocaine and each other while making bad choices, but once the plot kicks in what a movie.  Absolutely compelling, entertaining and satisfying chaos. It keeps you locked in waiting to see what will happen next. The whole movie you have no idea what will happen next.

While undeniably funny at times, I can’t help but find Anora incredibly miscalculated, both in marketing and its execution. A film trying to mix the hysteria and anxiety of the Safdies’ Uncut Gems and the off-beat hilarity and tone of Zola into an attempted cerebral character study. Anora’s character feels underdeveloped and sidelined. her feelings, decisions, and motivations unexplained and incoherent. Bizarre turn in from a reliable filmmaker in Baker. Questionable dialogue, questionable direction, a whole lot of questions from me.edit from march 2nd, 2025; worst best picture winner ever
